project_metadata.paper_title: FAIMS Mobile: Flexible, open-source software for field research
project_metadata.research_context: FAIMS Mobile is open-source, customisable software designed for field data collection across multiple disciplines. The paper describes the software architecture, features, and impact on field research practice.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile has been under development since 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

evidence.evidence_text: Current code version is 2.5
evidence.verbatim_quote: Current code version 2.5

evidence.evidence_text: Software licensed under GPLv3
evidence.verbatim_quote: Legal Code License GPLv3

evidence.evidence_text: Software uses Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq, NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium
evidence.verbatim_quote: Software code languages, tools, and services used Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq (non-free), NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium

evidence.evidence_text: Code repository at GitHub: https://github.com/ElsevierSoftwareX/SOFTX-D-17-00021
evidence.verbatim_quote: Permanent link to repository used for this code version https://github.com/ElsevierSoftwareX/SOFTX-D-17-00021

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times since first public release in 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently)

evidence.evidence_text: 29 confirmed field deployments with 9 including multiple field seasons
evidence.verbatim_quote: with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

evidence.evidence_text: Approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 hours using the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
evidence.verbatim_quote: Considering only FAIMS-led development, approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

evidence.evidence_text: Three deployment case studies published in Sobotkova et al., 2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

evidence.evidence_text: Android 6+ required for mobile application
evidence.verbatim_quote: Installation requirements & dependencies Android 6+, Ubuntu 16.04

evidence.evidence_text: Current software version is 2.5.20
evidence.verbatim_quote: Current software version 2.5.20

evidence.evidence_text: Well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days
evidence.verbatim_quote: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system if data and workflow models are available (well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days)

evidence.evidence_text: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance
evidence.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: Due to the need for significant QA per deployment, FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules

evidence.evidence_text: Applications built for discrete tasks exist for structural geology (GeoCline, Rocklogger for Android)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Some tools exist for discrete tasks, such as measuring strikes and dips for structural geology (e.g., GeoCline or Rocklogger for Android)

evidence.evidence_text: ARK, Heurist, and Kora all require continuous connection to a server
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora, which all require a continuous connection to a server

evidence.evidence_text: ODK was designed for social surveys where investigator asks questions of interviewee
evidence.verbatim_quote: ODK was designed for social surveys, where an investigator asks questions of a interviewee. FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world

evidence.evidence_text: Projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile using both detailed definition packet approach and simplified DSL-based method
evidence.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method

evidence.evidence_text: Funding from NeCTAR RT043 and V005, ARC LE140100151, and NSW Government RAAP
evidence.verbatim_quote: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program

evidence.evidence_text: Funding from Macquarie University, Flinders University, La Trobe University, Southern Cross University, University of Queensland, University of Sydney, UNSW Australia, CSIRO ON Prime programme
evidence.verbatim_quote: Macquarie University, Flinders University, La Trobe University, Southern Cross University, the University of Queensland, the University of Sydney, UNSW Australia, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ON Prime programme

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime
evidence.verbatim_quote: Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Sqlite3 to store attribute-key-value datastore with schemas definable at runtime
evidence.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs
evidence.verbatim_quote: An append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Beanshell for runtime scripting via calls to underlying Java API
evidence.verbatim_quote: Beanshell to provide runtime scripting via calls to an underlying Java API

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Spatialite to encode geospatial data and Nutiteq to render it
evidence.verbatim_quote: Spatialite to encode geospatial data in the datastore; Nutiteq to render geospatial data

evidence.evidence_text: Server uses Ruby on Rails/Apache stack for synchronisation, version review, and user management
evidence.verbatim_quote: A Ruby on Rails/Apache stack to provide a server for synchronisation, version review, user management, and similar tasks, which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS 2016-2018 NSW RAAP award funding community heritage and citizen science applications
evidence.verbatim_quote: A 2016–2018 New South Wales Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications

evidence.evidence_text: Users reported more complete, consistent, and granular data using FAIMS
evidence.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

evidence.evidence_text: Information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists
evidence.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists, which in one case improved 'post-excavation reconstruction of the site' and facilitated the evaluation of patterns for meaning in another

evidence.evidence_text: Time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset time required to implement FAIMS
evidence.verbatim_quote: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

evidence.evidence_text: Moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice making implicit knowledge explicit
evidence.verbatim_quote: They also observed that the process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice, during which knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

evidence.evidence_text: iDig created by American School of Classical Studies at Athens is an example of bespoke software
evidence.verbatim_quote: Bespoke software is expensive to build and maintain, placing it beyond the reach of all but the best-funded projects and organisations (e.g., iDig, created by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens:

evidence.evidence_text: Example of repurposed software: suite of iOS applications at Pompeii
evidence.verbatim_quote: Repurposed software requires field researchers to make do with applications designed for other contexts, which lack critical features but still require extensive customisation (cf. the use of a suite of iOS applications at Pompeii

evidence.evidence_text: Ben Carter's combination of KoBoToolbox, PostGIS, QGIS, LibreOffice Base, and pgadminIII as example of repurposed software suite
evidence.verbatim_quote: or Ben Carter's combination of KoBoToolbox, PostGIS, QGIS, LibreOffice Base, and pgadminIII

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate arbitrary data collection methodology
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology (schema and workflow), save records to a datastore, and opportunistically synchronise that data with a server and from there to other mobile devices

evidence.evidence_text: ODK 2.0 Tool Suite bi-directional synchronisation is in alpha release
evidence.verbatim_quote: bi-directional synchronisation across all devices (a feature in ODK 2.0 Tool Suite, which is in alpha release)

evidence.evidence_text: ODK Sensors is in alpha release
evidence.verbatim_quote: support for a wider range of external sensors and peripherals like label printers ('ODK Sensors' is in alpha release)

evidence.evidence_text: First research publications based on FAIMS-generated data will appear in 2018
evidence.verbatim_quote: The first research publications based on data generated using FAIMS will appear in 2018

evidence.evidence_text: Most uptake has been at large, multi-year projects still early in lifecycle
evidence.verbatim_quote: Most uptake has been at large, multi-year projects that are still early in their lifecycle, so FAIMS-related publications to date have focused on the software itself or the transition from paper-based to digital workflows

evidence.evidence_text: Each customisation and deployment is a miniature software development project
evidence.verbatim_quote: Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project

evidence.evidence_text: Documentation available at Module Cookbook and Beanshell API
evidence.verbatim_quote: Link to developer documentation/manual Module Cookbook https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/x/RgAu Module Beanshell API https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/x/RwAu

evidence.evidence_text: User to Developer documentation available at GitHub and perma.cc archive
evidence.verbatim_quote: 'User to Developer' documentation https://github.com/FAIMS/UserToDev; https://perma.cc/M4B3-JJEA

evidence.evidence_text: Support email at support@fedarch.org
evidence.verbatim_quote: Support email for questions support@fedarch.org

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is mature software
claims.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has been iteratively developed with field researchers for five years
claims.verbatim_quote: including five years of iterative co-development with field researchers first in archaeology, and more recently in geoscience, history, and ecology

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is open-source software
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is open-source software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems Project

claims.claim_text: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible
claims.verbatim_quote: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible, accommodating arbitrary research designs

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile consists of core Java and Ruby software providing a platform for data capture
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile consists of 'core' Java and Ruby software providing a platform for data capture, which can be deeply customised using 'definition packets' consisting of XML documents (data schema and UI) and Beanshell scripts (automation)

claims.claim_text: Comprehensive documentation is available for FAIMS Mobile
claims.verbatim_quote: 'FAIMS User to Developer Documentation' is designed to walk users through the creation of a module from first principles

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake despite representing significant socio-technical change
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the transition to digital recording during fieldwork represents a significant socio-technical change, FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile can be deployed across multiple disciplines
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is a native Android application supported by an Ubuntu server facilitating human-mediated field research across disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has been used for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
claims.verbatim_quote: approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

claims.claim_text: FAIMS deployment approach has been validated through case studies
claims.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

claims.claim_text: Users benefited from increased efficiency of fieldwork using FAIMS
claims.verbatim_quote: Three case studies involving archaeological deployments showed that users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is designed for rapid prototyping and easy redeployability
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, it is designed for rapid prototyping using and easy redeployability to reduce the costs of implementation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile makes digital recording more feasible and less costly for researchers
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile makes digital recording a more feasible and less costly option for researchers

claims.claim_text: Quality assurance is critical for FAIMS deployments
claims.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

claims.claim_text: Quality assurance is often neglected in academic software
claims.verbatim_quote: quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile supports automated testing with Robotium
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface

claims.claim_text: Complex field data collection has been neglected in software development
claims.verbatim_quote: Insufficient attention has been paid to the development of software specifically designed for digital data collection during field research

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is designed for offline use
claims.verbatim_quote: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is differentiated from other field data collection software by offline capability
claims.verbatim_quote: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora, which all require a continuous connection to a server

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is differentiated from ODK by its archaeological origins
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK) and its variants, but is differentiated by its lineage

claims.claim_text: FAIMS originated in archaeology recording observations about material world rather than survey questions
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world, relationships between those observations, and metadata contextualising the collection of those observations

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile can be customised independently without FAIMS team involvement
claims.verbatim_quote: projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method

claims.claim_text: FAIMS provides 'User to Developer' documentation to support do-it-yourself customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: We also provide 'User to Developer' documentation to support do-it-yourself customisation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Project has received substantial multi-institutional funding support
claims.verbatim_quote: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture allows rendering arbitrary data schemas at runtime
claims.verbatim_quote: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology (schema and workflow)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS uses attribute-key-value datastore with runtime-definable schemas
claims.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS uses append-only datastore providing complete version histories
claims.verbatim_quote: An append-only datastore that provides a version history for all records

claims.claim_text: FAIMS supports more profound customisation without modification of core software
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS, conversely, supports more profound customisation without modification of core software

claims.claim_text: FAIMS includes mobile GIS capabilities for raster and vector data
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS has GIS rendering capabilities for raster (Figs. 3, 4), or vector data

claims.claim_text: FAIMS server can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: A Ruby on Rails/Apache stack to provide a server for synchronisation, version review, user management, and similar tasks, which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

claims.claim_text: FAIMS provides automated bidirectional synchronisation across all devices
claims.verbatim_quote: Automated, bidirectional synchronisation of all data across an unlimited number of devices using a local or online server

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is being extended to community heritage and citizen science applications
claims.verbatim_quote: A 2016–2018 New South Wales Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications

claims.claim_text: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation, which often occurred long after field recording when the context of the record had been forgotten, or the person who made the record was no longer available

claims.claim_text: FAIMS produces more complete, consistent, and granular data
claims.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

claims.claim_text: FAIMS improves information exchange between excavators and specialists
claims.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists

claims.claim_text: FAIMS dramatically reduces or eliminates manual digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS allows the efficient collection of field data, dramatically reducing or eliminating manual digitisation

claims.claim_text: Time savings from FAIMS result in more data collected during fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

claims.claim_text: Transition to digital recording makes implicit field practice knowledge explicit
claims.verbatim_quote: the process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice, during which knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

claims.claim_text: Bespoke software is expensive and beyond reach of most projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Bespoke software is expensive to build and maintain, placing it beyond the reach of all but the best-funded projects and organisations

claims.claim_text: Repurposed software lacks critical features and requires extensive customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Repurposed software requires field researchers to make do with applications designed for other contexts, which lack critical features but still require extensive customisation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture resembles distinction between web browser and website
claims.verbatim_quote: This distinction between the 'core' client and the definition packet resembles the one between a web browser and a website

claims.claim_text: FAIMS has features not found in ODK including bidirectional synchronisation
claims.verbatim_quote: It also includes features not found in ODK: more nuanced relationships between entities, bi-directional synchronisation across all devices

claims.claim_text: FAIMS has wider range of external sensor and peripheral support than ODK
claims.verbatim_quote: support for a wider range of external sensors and peripherals like label printers

claims.claim_text: FAIMS-related publications to date focused on software and workflow transition rather than research results
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS-related publications to date have focused on the software itself or the transition from paper-based to digital workflows

claims.claim_text: Most FAIMS uptake at large multi-year projects early in lifecycle
claims.verbatim_quote: Most uptake has been at large, multi-year projects that are still early in their lifecycle

claims.claim_text: Each FAIMS customisation is a miniature software development project
claims.verbatim_quote: Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project

claims.claim_text: Researchers gained familiarity with software development through FAIMS deployment
claims.verbatim_quote: By participating in a 'miniature software development project', researchers gained familiarity with the strengths, limits, and demands of software, especially the need for extensive testing

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile can support socio-technical transition from paper to digital in field research
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community-driven, customisable, extensible software that can support the socio-technical transition from paper to digital in field research disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is generalised software combining field research features with customisability
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile, conversely, is 'generalised' software which combines features required for field research with sufficient customisability to allow its use across disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS improves transparency and reproducibility through comprehensive datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: It also promotes synthetic research and improves transparency and reproducibility through the production of comprehensive datasets that can be mapped to vocabularies or ontologies as they are created

claims.claim_text: Field research disciplines often lack transparency and reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Field research disciplines, however, often lack transparency and reproducibility, compromising the integrity of research results

claims.claim_text: Field data is often collected using ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments, and bespoke databases
claims.verbatim_quote: Field data is often collected using an ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments in various formats, and bespoke databases

claims.claim_text: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible
claims.verbatim_quote: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible. Deficiencies like these inhibit reuse of primary data and the aggregation of datasets from multiple studies for large-scale research

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK but customisation is more entailed
claims.verbatim_quote: In short, FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK, but as a result customisation is more entailed

claims.claim_text: Greatest challenge of transition from paper is reallocation of time from end of project to beginning
claims.verbatim_quote: The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time from the end of a project (digitisation) to the beginning (data modelling, development, and testing), even if an overall time-savings is realised

claims.claim_text: Customisable data export can format data for existing services or standards
claims.verbatim_quote: Customisable data export can format data for existing services or standards (e.g., archaeological records can be exported not only as shapefiles, CSVs, or a 3NF relational database for incorporation into an existing geodatabase, but also as XML or GeoJSON for ingest into domain-specific repositories like Open Context)

claims.claim_text: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies to link to shared vocabularies, thesauri, or ontologies
claims.verbatim_quote: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements, connecting them to linked open data sources

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is community-driven and organisations with development capacity can contribute to core software
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community driven; if current or potential users request new features, they can be implemented (within resource constraints). Researchers can also build and share their own customisations, while organisations with sufficient development capacity are welcome to contribute directly to the core software

claims.claim_text: Near-real-time availability of data from multiple devices provides immediate error detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Near-real-time availability of data from multiple devices for review also provides immediate error detection (especially when combined with validation)

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Open-source licensing is preferable to proprietary licensing for research software infrastructure
trigger_text: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents open-source nature as inherently positive without explicit justification, assuming readers share the value judgment that open-source licensing benefits research communities

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Field researchers will adopt digital tools if they meet discipline-specific needs
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake
appealing to a large enough user base to support its development
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument for generalised software assumes that appropriate features will overcome resistance to digital transition, bridging claims about user needs to adoption outcomes

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Offline capability is essential for field research software
trigger_text: It is designed for offline use
allowing devices to work in network-degraded environments or offline for extended periods of time
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper treats offline capability as a critical feature without explicitly arguing why network connectivity is unreliable in field contexts

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Customisation complexity is an acceptable trade-off for powerful features
trigger_text: FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK, but as a result customisation is more entailed
Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper acknowledges complexity but presents it as worthwhile, assuming field researchers will accept increased effort for better capabilities

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Archaeological field recording requirements are representative of field research more broadly
trigger_text: facilitating human-mediated field research across disciplines
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper extends software designed for archaeology to multiple disciplines without explicit justification that archaeological needs generalise

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Version history tracking is valuable for research data integrity
trigger_text: use of an append-only datastore that provides a version history for all records
full revision history, including the ability to review and reverse changes to records selectively
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents version history as inherently valuable without arguing why tracking all changes matters for research reproducibility

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Standardised vocabularies and ontologies improve data compatibility and reuse
trigger_text: comprehensive datasets that can be mapped to vocabularies or ontologies as they are created
URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper assumes linked data benefits without explaining why ontology mapping improves research outcomes

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Adoption metrics (customisations, deployments, user hours) are valid indicators of software success
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times
approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents usage statistics as evidence of impact without arguing why these metrics indicate actual research benefit

research_designs.design_text: Iterative co-development with field researchers across multiple disciplines
research_designs.verbatim_quote: five years of iterative co-development with field researchers first in archaeology, and more recently in geoscience, history, and ecology

study_design.design_description: Iterative development incorporating user feedback across multiple field disciplines over five years
study_design.design_rationale: To ensure software meets actual field research needs across disciplines

research_designs.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community driven; if current or potential users request new features, they can be implemented (within resource constraints). Researchers can also build and share their own customisations, while organisations with sufficient development capacity are welcome to contribute directly to the core software

study_design.design_description: Community-driven model allowing user contributions, customisation sharing, and direct core software contributions
study_design.design_rationale: To enable community ownership and sustainable development

research_designs.design_text: Case study validation approach for documenting deployment outcomes
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

study_design.design_description: Published case studies documenting archaeological deployments to validate software utility
study_design.design_rationale: To provide detailed evidence of software impact in real field contexts

methods.method_text: Requirements gathering through field researcher collaboration
methods.verbatim_quote: During a typical FAIMS-led deployment, researchers work with FAIMS Project staff to articulate their data model and workflow
A developer then renders that methodology into a 'definition packet' of files that produce a 'module'
leveraging online software version control systems like GitHub

methods.method_text: User impact assessment through deployment tracking
methods.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently), with 29 confirmed field deployments
FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface
Opportunistic synchronisation whenever a connection is available, allowing devices to work in network-degraded environments or offline for extended periods of time

methods.method_text: XML-based domain specific language for simplified customisation
methods.verbatim_quote: FAIMS has developed a XML-based domain specific language (DSL) to simplify customisation. Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet

methods.method_text: Customisable data export to multiple formats
methods.verbatim_quote: Customisable export to desktop software, pre-existing databases, or online data services (using SQL queries)

protocols.protocol_text: Collaborative data model and workflow articulation process
protocols.verbatim_quote: researchers work with FAIMS Project staff to articulate their data model and workflow

protocols.protocol_text: Definition packet creation using XML, Beanshell, and CSS
protocols.verbatim_quote: Separate definition packet files offer nuanced control of the data schema (XML), the user interface (XML and CSS), and automation and logic (Beanshell)

protocols.protocol_text: Localisation using plain text file for multilingual support
protocols.verbatim_quote: The interface can also be translated into multiple languages using a (plain text) localisation file

protocols.protocol_text: GitHub repository management for code and module sharing
protocols.verbatim_quote: Users who are satisfied with one of the many modules in our GitHub library can also simply instantiate an existing customisation

protocols.protocol_text: Deployment tracking and user hour logging
trigger_text: approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h
protocols.inference_reasoning: Usage statistics imply a logging mechanism for tracking deployments and hours, though specific protocol not described

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No description of how usage hours are tracked
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot verify accuracy of usage statistics

protocols.protocol_text: Robotium automated testing for load testing modules
protocols.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface. This allows users to load-test their modules under simulated field conditions

Automated, bidirectional synchronisation of all data across an unlimited number of devices using a local or online server. Replication of the entire datastore on each device, not caching, provides robust offline capability

protocols.protocol_text: DSL-based module generation from single file
protocols.verbatim_quote: Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet, at the expense of some loss of independent control over each element of a customisation
Customisable export to desktop software, pre-existing databases, or online data services (using SQL queries)

sources: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme
New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ON Prime programme
funding.acknowledgement_text: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program, Macquarie University, Flinders University, La Trobe University, Southern Cross University, the University of Queensland, the University of Sydney, UNSW Australia, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ON Prime programme, and fees paid by our users for consultation, customisation, deployment, and support services.

machine_actionability.rationale: Software paper - no research data to share
Software available via multiple channels (GitHub, Google Play, direct APK), comprehensive documentation, perma.cc archive links for persistence

conflicts_of_interest.declaration: Not stated - authors are developers of the software being described

ethics_approval.details: Software publication - no human subjects research

permits_and_authorizations.details: Software publication - no fieldwork permits required

items.description: An introductory video related to this article

fair_assessment.assessment_notes: Excellent FAIR compliance for software: DOI assigned, multiple access points (GitHub, Google Play, direct download), GPLv3 licence, comprehensive documentation, perma.cc archive links for persistence. Minor deduction for Findable (no ORCID for authors), minor deduction for Interoperable (Nutiteq dependency is non-free).

known_limitations: Paper is methodological software publication rather than empirical research
Impact claims rely on self-reported usage metrics
Case study evidence referenced but not included in this paper
pass_history: Pass 1-2: Claims and evidence extraction complete (43 evidence, 59 claims)
Pass 3-5: RDMAP extraction complete (3 designs, 8 methods, 9 protocols)
